metadata.title: Catalytic deep combustion characteristics of benzene over cobalt doped Mn-Ce solid solution catalysts at lower temperatures

State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 China 1 These authors contributed equally to the present study. Graphical abstract In this paper, CoxMn1−xCeOδ mixed oxides were synthesized using a co-precipitation method. The catalyst’s performance for the benzene combustion reaction was evaluated, and Co0.25Mn0.75CeOδ (CMC-0.25) exhibited good catalytic activity, stability and CO2 selectivity. The prepared catalysts were characterized and analyzed completely by XRD, BET, Raman, TEM and HRTEM, XPS, H2-TPR, and O2-TPD. The results demonstrated that a solid solution was formed with more active oxygen induced by Co doping. Strong interaction effects among Co-Mn-Ce-O were speculated as the main mechanisms underlying the high-efficiency catalytic capacity. The prepared Co-doped Mn-Ce mixed oxides catalyst may be a potential low-cost catalyst alternative to replace industrial noble metal catalysts. Keywords CoxMn1−xCeOδ Combustion reaction Solid solution Active oxygen Low-cost catalyst 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are an unfortunate by-product of rapid industrialization, especially in petrochemistry, the coating and printing industry, medicine and the detergent industry. Strict standards and legislations have been established to control the emission of VOCs because of their contributions to ozone generation and photochemical smog, as well as their harmful properties that can be toxic, mutagenic, malodorous, or carcinogenic [1]. Meanwhile, many treatment techniques such as activated carbon, absorption, non-thermal plasmas, biotricking filter and direct combustion have been adopted to remove them. In recent decades, catalytic combustion has been considered as an ideal way for VOCs to be removed due to its low working temperature, smaller resource consumption, high carbonization efficiency and lack of additional pollution [2]. The development of a high-performance catalyst has attracted significant attention due to its key role in the catalytic oxidation system [3]. In the removal of VOCs, supported noble metals and transition metal oxides catalysts have been commonly studied. From the standpoint of low temperature catalysis for the oxidation of VOCs, supported noble metals catalysts have gained increased research interest [1,4]. However, due to the high cost, poor stability at higher temperature and lower resistance to poisoning, more general applications of precious metal catalysts have been limited [5]. Although transition metal oxides catalysts are lower cost, have a long lifetime and a high resistance to poisoning, they generally are less active than the supported noble metal in purifying VOCs [6]. This conflict has sparked research interest in hybrid oxide catalysts [7]. Recently, MnOx-CeO2 solid solution catalysts [8–12] that possess high oxygen storage capacity (OSC) and multiple valences have exhibited superior performance in various catalytic reactions, such as ammonia oxidation, catalytic reduction of NO by SCR with NH3 in the presence of oxygen [13] and NOx decomposition. Furthermore, MnOx-CeO2 was also found to be highly active in the combustion of CO and VOCs at lower operational temperatures; this result was directly theorized to be caused by the strong interaction effect of MnOx-CeO2 and more reactive oxygen types (O2 −, O2 2− and O−) at the interface between the MnOx and CeO2 lattice [7,14]. Venkataswamy et al. [15] produced a material that demonstrated extraordinary improvement in CO oxidation activity by manganese doped ceria solid solutions. Zhen Wang, et al. [16] also reported that CeO2-MnOx composites exhibited much higher catalytic activity for benzene oxidation, and they attributed this result to a balance in the lattice oxygen atoms between catalytic oxidation and reduction. Cobalt oxides have been widely investigated as catalysts, and Co3O4 has been of particular interest as a p-type semiconductor containing lots of electron deficiencies [17–21] that facilitate oxygen adsorption, because electrons can be transferred from the metal cations easily to form activated species [5]. More recently, Shen and his co-workers [22] synthesized a series of Mn-site partially substituted LaCoxMn1−xO3(x = 0–0.5) catalysts by using an impregnation method with citrate; these catalysts possessed high-valence Mn-site cations and large lattice oxygen content. This catalyst shows obvious advantages in contrast to LaMnO3. They found that doping of Co2+ not only leads to lattice defects in LaMnO3 but also causes distortion in the surface lattice and consequently increases surface energy, which has an appreciable effect on the adsorption ability of the catalyst. In another work [23], Mn-Co-Ce mixed oxides were synthesized, and researchers found that the formation of (Mn,Co)3O4 mixed spinels have remarkable performance for CO preferential oxidation(COPROX). Zhao and co-workers added Co3O4 to CexMn1−xO2 composites to accelerate the COPROX reaction [24]. Guo et al. investigated high Co doping in Co-Mn-Ce mixed oxides and observed good efficiency in CO conversion [25,26]. Based on this background, we, therefore, found it was possible to synthesize Co-doped MnOx-CeO2 catalysts for deep catalytic combustion of VOCs, and these results have great potential for developing noble-metal-free catalysts. In this study, we synthesized a series of Co-doped Mn-Ce (CoxMn1−xCeOδ x = 0–1) catalysts using a co-precipitation method by regulating the Co/(Mn + Co) molar ratio. To produce the most active catalyst, we evaluated the performance of all samples for the total combustion of the typical VOC benzene. Furthermore, the stability and water-resistant of the high-performance catalyst were also investigated at different temperatures for more than 3600 min in the benzene combustion reaction. The techniques of X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), H2 temperature programmed (H2-TPR), O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were employed to investigate Co-doped Mn-Ce catalytic performance, the formation of Co-Mn-Ce-O solid solution and the relationships among these properties in the benzene catalytic combustion reaction. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalytic preparation A series of CoxMn1−xCeOδ catalysts were prepared by a co-precipitation method, The desired amounts solutions of the following nitrates were used: Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O, Ce(NO3)2·6H2O acting as hydrate precursors. Firstly, stoichiometric amount of the precursors were dissolved in deionized water and added dropwise into aqueous ammonia solution (pH = 9.5–10.5) with stirring at room temperature for 12 h. Then, the obtained precipitate was filtered off and repeatedly washed with deionized water until the pH reached 7.0. Finally, the powders were dried at 105 °C for 6 h and further calcined in air at 500 °C for 8 h with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. Ultimately, the CoxMn1−xCeOδ catalysts were obtained. The synthesized catalysts were designated as CMC-R, where R represents the molar ratio of Co/(Mn + Co) and (Mn + Co)/Ce = 1. 2.2 Characterization To identify the crystal structures of the as-prepared catalysts, XRD was applied in an AXS D8 advance diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromatic and Cu Kα radiation source(0.15418 nm). The diffraction scattering angle (2θ) was set from 5 to 80° using a scan rate of 0.02° min−1. H2-TPR experiments using an Autochem 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) provided the automated catalyst characterization system. In these tests, 50 mg of the purged samples were used under a flow of a mixture gas (5% H2/Ar, 25 ml/min) with a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1 from room temperature to 700 °C. The Raman spectra of the samples were measured using a DXR532 Laser Raman spectrometer equipped with a 532 nm laser as an excitation and 10 mW laser power. The XPS patterns were operated on a PHI-5000C ESCA system (upgraded by RBD company, America) using a dual Mg/Al Kα anode at 250 W and running at 14KV with a pressure range of 10−8 Torr. Charging of the catalyst samples was corrected by setting the binding energy of adventitious carbon (C1s) to 284.5 eV. The surface area and pore size distribution measurements were carried out on an ASAP 2020 by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at liquid nitrogen (−196 °C) using the BET and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods. Prior to runtime analyses, the samples were previously degassed at 350 °C for 4 h. The O2-TPD was also tested on an Autochem 2920 (Micromeritics, USA), and the samples were pre-treated at 150 °C under Ar flow. The samples were then treated with 30 ml/min of mixture gas (5% O2, 95% Ar) for 2 h at room temperature and then heated up to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. The TEM and HRTEM studies were carried out on a JEOL-2010 microscope at a voltage of 200 kV. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic deep combustion of benzene was carried out in an experimental system with a continuous-flow fixed bed to allow for efficient data acquisition and activity evaluation under atmospheric pressure. Approximately 500 mg of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was loaded in the middle of the quartz tube (i.d. 7 mm) and placed inside a temperature-controlled thermocouple furnace with a temperature range from 150 °C to 300 °C. The reactant gas was composed of 1000 ppm benzene and air with a WHSV of 90,000 ml g−1 h−1. The inlet and outlet gases were analyzed using an on-line gas chromatograph (Shimazu GC-2014) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to determine gas compositions. In addition, so as ensure the accuracy of the data purification, each tested temperature was kept constant for approximately 30 min. Selectivity of CO2 was obtained by the following equation: Y CO 2 = F CO 2 ν F VOC where F CO 2 is the outlet molar flow-rate of CO2, and ν is the number of carbon atoms in the VOC molecule (for benzene, ν = 6) and FVOC in is the inlet molar flow-rate of VOC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization studies The XRD patterns in the 2θ range of 10–80° are shown in Fig. 1 a for the ceria-based catalysts with different Co/(Mn + Co) atomic ratios. The CMC-0 sample shows a typical cubic fluorite phase of ceria (JCDS 43–1002) and no manganese oxides, such as MnO2, Mn2O3 or other oxide phases. This notable result suggests that Mn ions are possibly substituted for Ce4+ in a fluorite lattice and form a solid solution in the manganese-doped ceria-based samples [27,28]. This suggestion is validated by the decrease in the lattice parameter from 5.4108 Å (for pure CeO2) to 5.4005 Å that is observed on the only Mn-doped ceria catalysts due to the smaller ionic radius of Mnn+ (Mn2+ = 0.081 nm, Mn3+ = 0.072 nm, Mn4+ = 0.067 nm) compared to Ce4+. The diffraction peaks of the CMC-R (R = 0.5, 0.75, 1) catalysts mainly are from the Co3O4 spinel (JCDS 43–1003) and CeO2 phases, which correspond to those found for the single oxides. In contrast, the XRD pattern of the CMC-0.25 catalyst does not show any diffraction by cobalt oxides, and only cubic fluorite structures of CeO2 are observed. This result indicates that the doping of Con+(Co2+ = 0.079 nm, Co3+ = 0.068 nm) ions into the ceria lattice in place of manganese decreases the lattice parameter. There are three kinds of cobalt oxides species likely to be present in the CMC-0.25 samples; (i) highly dispersed CoOx on the surface of MnOx-CeO2, (ii) an amorphous phase and (iii) Co ions dispersed into the ceria lattice in place of Mn ions [15,29]. In addition, compared with CMC-0, the lattice parameter of ceria in CMC-0.25 catalysts exhibits a clear shrinkage along the α axis (from 5.4005 Å to 5.3916 Å), and the diffraction peaks of CeO2 are slightly shifted towards higher values of the Bragg angle for the (111) peak (Fig. 1b). These distinct features indicate that the Mn and Co ions are incorporated into the cubic lattice and form a Co-Mn-CeOδ solid solution. However, the diffraction pattern of the CMC-0.5 catalyst indicates that crystallization of Co3O4 occurred, and this result may be due to phase separation of Co-Mn-CeOδ solid solutions. Co is dispersed in the cubic phase of ceria and also occurred in an individual cubic Co3O4 phase at 2θ = 36.85, 59.35, as shown in Fig. 1a. The weak diffraction peaks of Co3O4 show that the Co3O4 content exceeds the maximum saturated solution of the CeO2 crystal lattice in the catalysts and leads to the formation of a Co3O4 crystal phase in the sample during the calcination process. The experimental results indicate that the phase composition of CoxMn1−xCeOδ oxides strongly depends on the molar ratios of manganese and cobalt oxides. The porous structures of CMC-R samples are further investigated by nitrogen sorption measurements. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore-size distributions are displayed in Fig. 2 , and their surface area, pore volume and pore size are summarized in Table 1 . It can been clearly seen that all of the samples showed distorted type-II isotherms with a type H3 hysteresis loop in the relative pressure (p/p0) range of 0.4-0.98. As shown in Table 1, we found that the CMC-0.25 material possessed a larger surface area than CMC-0 and CMC-1; this result suggests that cobalt doping is beneficial for increasing the surface area. To check the redox properties of the new series of CMC-R catalysts, H2-TPR experiments were performed. In Fig. 3 , the reduction curves of all samples are shown. Similar to previous findings [16], CMC-0 solid solution exhibits two overlapped strong reduction peaks at ∼250 and 335 °C, respectively. This observation is the typical characteristic of a two-step reduction of Mn2O3. The low temperature peak is attributed to the reducible manganese species corresponding with the reduction of MnO2 to Mn3O4, and the high temperature peak corresponds to the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO when the surface capping oxygen of CeO2 is reduced [14,30]. The H2-TPR profile of the CMC-1 oxide shows two reduction peaks at approximately 320 and 360 °C, and this result is also due to a two-step process. The low temperature peak is due to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, and the high temperature reduction peak is results from the further reduction of CoO to metallic cobalt along with partial surface Ce4+ reduction [31]. It is noteworthy that the reduction profiles were more complicated as more Co was added into the ceria lattice of the CMC-0 solid solution, and the reduction behaviors of these oxides were dependent on the atomic ratio of Co/(Mn + Co). Accordingly, the increase in reduction temperatures may be attributed to the segregation of Co3O4 and the solid solution at the atomic ratio R > 0.5. As we show, CMC-0.25 displays a lower reduction temperature from other CMC oxides, and three continuous peaks (230, 286, 328 °C) over the temperature range 200–350 °C are clearly detected. This result is attributed to the interaction between MnCeO and CoO of the solid solution. Meanwhile, a peak corresponding to the reduction of CeO2 is also found. Furthermore, the formation of the CMC-0.25 solid solution facilitates the mobility of oxygen species from the bulk to the surface and creates more active sites for the adsorption of hydrogen [32]. Based on these observations, we conclude that Co ion doping in the CMC-0 solid solution can result in a better catalyst for benzene oxidation. The Raman spectra of CMC-R samples are shown in Fig. 4 . The bi-component Mn-Ce shows a single peak at 461 cm−1 that is attributed to the formation of the Mn-Ce-O solid solution. This band exhibited a significantly shift compared with the triply degenerate F 2g (465 cm−1) band of pure CeO2 from previous literature [33]. The CMC-0.25 sample exhibited widening and a slight shift to a lower wavenumber for the F2g band with respect to the CMC-0 spectrum. This may be due to the formation of oxygen vacancies and also suggests the formation of the CMC-0.25 solid solution. As the content of cobalt incorporation increases and manganese decreases, three new bands appear approximately 195 cm−1, 519 cm−1, 687 cm−1 in the CMC-0.5 sample that can be assigned to the Co-O-Co Raman-activated modes of Co3O4 [25]. Furthermore, in the CMC-0.75 spectrum, the intensity of the F 2g band decreased. In contrast, the intensity of the signals of Co3O4 increased, and two new peaks of Co3O4 (at 475 cm−1, 612 cm−1) also are observed. For CMC-1, a material with a spectrum similar to the spectra for the CMC-0.75 system, six distinct modes appear. The F 2g band of CeO2 (∼462 cm−1) and five Raman-active modes (A1g + Eg + 3F2g) of spinel Co3O4 [34,35]. Three bands at 195, 519, 621 cm−1 can be assigned to the F2g mode, whereas the Raman modes at 687 and 484 cm−1 have respective sym-metries of A1g and Eg, and attributed to the octahedral sites [CoO6] in the O h 7 symmetry and the vibration of octahedral site [19]. In order to study the oxidation state and composition of catalyst surface species, XPS spectra for the Ce 3d, Mn 2p, Co 2p and O 1 s core levels of CMC-0 and CMC-0.25 were recorded. These spectra are shown in Fig. 5 , and the surface composition and atomic ratios are compiled in Table 2 . In addition, the Shirley background and Gaussian-Lorenz model functions were used to fit the peak of Ce 3d, Mn 2p, Co 2p and O 1s. The XPS spectra of the Ce 3d core levels of two samples along with the five pairs of spin-orbit components were illustrated in Fig. 5a. In this figure the labels v, v″, v‴, u, u″, u‴ refer to three pairs of spin-orbit doublets that were observed and are consistent with the characteristics of Ce4+ 3d states. The other four peaks, denoted by v°, v′, u°, u′, correspond to the Ce3+ 3d final states. Therefore, it can be inferred that Ce4+ and Ce3+ ions co-exist on the surface of the two samples [36]. Clearly, the incorporation of Co resulted in a high concentration of Ce3+ ions compared to the CMC-0 solid solution and created a charge imbalance, more oxygen vacancies and an unsaturated structure on the catalyst surface. These phenomena might be the reason why the CMC-0.25 sample is more active for the benzene oxidation reaction than CMC-0 catalyst. The XPS spectra of the core levels of the Mn 2p in CMC-0 and CMC-0.25 samples are illustrated in Fig. 5b, in which the Mn 2p doublet can be observed. The Mn 2p exhibited two peaks: a Mn 2p3/2 component at 641.4 eV and a Mn 2p1/2 component at 652.9 eV with a spin-orbit splitting of ΔE = 11.5 eV. According to previous literature, the observed binding energies correspond to a mixed valence of Mn3+ and Mn4+ species [37]. In addition, a distinct identification of Mn2+ and Mn3+ is difficult due to the small difference in their binding energies [15]. It is worth nothing that the Mn4+/(Mn3+ + Mn2+)ratio was decreased due to the doping of cobalt, as shown in Table 2. As showed in Fig. S1 in the supplementary materials, doublet splitting of 4.63 eV was obtained for CMC-0, resulting in an AOS of 3.74, which is higher than the CMC-0.25 of 3.62(△Es = 4.74 eV). The lower AOS implies the higher fraction of Mn2+ and Mn3+ [38,39], which is consistent with the information from Mn 2p. It has been reported that Mn2+ and Mn3+ have better catalytic VOC activity compared to Mn4+ [2]. Fig. 5c shows the Co 2p core level spectra of the CMC-0.25 solid solution catalyst. The XPS spectra of the Co 2p exhibites two spin-orbit doublets and two shake-up satellite peaks. The two spin-orbit doublets in the Co 2p spectra are apparent at binding energies of 779.5 ± 0.4 eV and 795.5 ± 0.4 eV and are attributed to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively. Two satellite peaks corresponding to the binding energies appear at approximately 785.5 eV and 801.3 eV. The observed binding energies suggest that Co is in its +2 and +3 oxidation states. According to the literature data [40,41], the spin-orbit value is 15.2 ± 0.2 eV and corresponds to Co3O4. Moreover, the presence of the satellite peaks with a low intensity at approximately 6 eV from the main Co 2p3/2 spin-orbit component is further evidence that Co2+ and Co3+ species are present [42]. Fig. 5d displays the O 1s core level spectra of the CMC-0 and CMC-0.25 samples. The figure shows that the O 1s spectrum can be fit with three peaks at 528.7, 531.1 and 532.58 eV, which can be attributed to lattice oxygen atoms (O2−, denoted as Oα), surface adsorbed oxygen (O2 −, O2 2−, O− denoted as Oβ), chemisorbed water and/or dissociated oxygen and/or hydroxyl species (Oγ), respectively [43,44]. As seen in Fig. 5d and Table 2, after Mn is partially substituted by Co, the concentration of Oβ increases from 40% to 50%; this result indicates that a change in structural arrangement and/or electronic structure has occurred due to the interaction between Ce-O and Co-O. Moreover, the Oβ/Oα molar ratio in CMC-0.25 catalyst was higher than in CMC-0 due to the charge imbalance caused by the doping of Co cations and the resulting neutralization by an increase in Oβ concentration. Thus, the doping of Co into the CMC-0 solid solution induces changes in the O(1s) chemical state and increases the amount of surface adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface, which enhanced the Oα mobility, resulting in an improvement in the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [45]. These effects may be responsible for the high catalytic activity of CMC-0.25 for benzene oxidation. The O2-TPD was used to determine the mobility of oxygen species in CMC-0 and CMC-0.25 catalysts, and the results of which are shown in Fig. 6 . Four desorption peaks can be observed from the CMC-0 sample. The peak at 114 °C corresponds to the oxygen molecule(O2). The peaks at 327 °C and 355 °C correspond to the oxygen molecule anion (O2 −) and oxygen anion (O−), respectively; these peaks arise from the oxygen active on the surface. The final peak at 559 °C may result from the desorption of surface lattice oxygen. The CMC-0.25 catalyst also presented four peaks, and the active oxygen peak intensity was greater than for CMC-0. This result indicates that the CMC-0.25 solid solution surface has abundant surface active oxygen species in the form of O2 −and O−. The CMC-0.25 catalyst has the same O2 desorption peak, but the peaks of the surface active oxygen and surface lattice oxygen were shifted to lower temperatures when compared to CMC-0 sample. This phenomenon is attributed to the lattice defects and oxygen vacancies that result from the interaction between MnOCo and CeO during the formation of the CMC-0.25 solid solution. According to the literature [46], lower oxygen desorption temperatures and larger intensities of desorption peaks contribute to oxygen activation and adsorption onto the oxidant surface and result in higher activity for benzene catalytic oxidation reaction by CMC-0.25 catalyst. In order to establish a correlation between the nanostructure and the catalytic oxidation activity of CMC-0.25 catalyst, the morphology, crystalline structure and particle size of the catalyst was recorded by TEM and is shown in Fig. 7 . Clearly, the catalyst nanocrystals have a hexagonal morphology with apparent nearly monodispersed particles of approximately 6–15 nm. Form high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images, the lattice spacing of fringes is 0.31 nm, which matches well with the parameters of the (111) plane of a fluorite-structured CMC-0.25 solid solution. It is important to note that the lattice fringes related to MnOx and Co3O4 are not detected from HRTEM images due to the formation of a well-crystallized solid solution, which is consistent with XRD results. 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic performance of CoxMn1−xCeOδ catalysts for benzene combustion as a function of reaction temperature is presented in Fig. 8 . CMC-0.25 catalysts appear to be superior for benzene catalytic combustion as compared to CMC-0 and CMC-1 catalysts and achieve complete benzene conversion at approximately 260 °C. It is worth pointing out that the reaction temperature of this sample was much lower than most of the noble-metal-free catalysts displayed in previous literatures, as shown in Table 3 . However, with the increase of Co/(Mn + Co) ratio, the sample exhibited higher T 50 and T 90(temperature at 50% and 90% benzene conversion) than that of CMC-0.25. This result can be attributed to the formation of the solid solution, the existence of the abundant oxygen vacancies, and the interaction effect between components oxides of CMC-0.25 catalyst. Specifically, the reaction rates of benzene oxidation normalized by the specific surface area (RS) of the catalyst were showed in Table 1. CMC-0.25 revealed the increased reaction rate (Rs = 7.811 × 10−3 mmol/m2 h−1) compared with the rates of CMC-0 (Rs = 4.567 × 10−3 mmol/m2 h−1) at 200 °C of the reaction temperature. This result also means that the most abundant active sites might be formed on the surface of CMC-0.25 as evidenced by the results from catalytic performance. The stability and CO2 selectivity represents the important performance of a catalyst for catalytic of VOCs. Therefore, the stability and CO2 selectivity of the CMC-0.25 catalyst were also inspected by analyzing the evolution of conversion over time-on-stream at alternating temperature conditions(250 °C for 1440 min, 240 °C for 1440 min, and 220 °C for 720 min) (Fig. 9 ). This experiment showed that after 3600 min of time-on-stream, the CMC-0.25 catalyst maintained 95–98% of benzene conversion at 250 °C, and the catalyst activity was stable at different temperature. Meanwhile, Benzene was completely oxidized to CO2 and H2O over the CMC-0.25 catalyst at 250 °C, then CO2 selectivity decrease occurred at 250 and 220 °C (still above 99.2%). However, along with the increase of temperature from 220 to 250 °C, no CO and other organic species were observed. To evaluate the effect of water vapor on the catalytic performance, on-stream benzene oxidation experiment was performed with 1.5% and 5.0%, respectively. As shown in Fig. 10 , the CMC-0.25 catalyst presented a better water-resistant with 1.5 vol% water vapor at 250 °C during the 720 min tests repeatedly, but when moisture concentration rose to 8.0 vol%, a small drop in benzene conversion from 95% to 90% took place mainly due to the competitive adsorption of benzene, oxygen and excessive water molecules on the catalysts surfaces [55]. 4 Conclusions We successfully synthesized Co-doped Mn-Ce-O solid solution catalysts, and their catalytic performance for benzene combustion was also tested. The CMC-0.25 catalyst possessed the superior low-temperature oxidation activity among these catalysts, and presented the appropriate for water-resistant, stability and CO2 selectivity. The doping of Co into the lattice of a Mn-Ce-O solid solution lowers the energy of oxygen vacancy and promotes the formation of more oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, increased oxygen vacancies and strong interaction effect among Co3O4 and MnOx and CeO2 species were responsible for the improvement in redox properties; thus, a high-performance CMC-0.25 catalyst was found for VOCs oxidation at low temperatures (∼250 °C). We believe that the efficient and sustainable CMC-0.25 catalyst could be a substitute for noble metal catalysts in oxidation of VOCs. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, CoxMn1−xCeOδ mixed oxides were synthesized using a co-precipitation method. The catalyst’s performance for the benzene combustion reaction was evaluated, and Co0.25Mn0.75CeOδ (CMC-0.25) exhibited good catalytic activity, stability and CO2 selectivity. The prepared catalysts were characterized and analyzed completely by XRD, BET, Raman, TEM and HRTEM, XPS, H2-TPR, and O2-TPD. The results demonstrated that a solid solution was formed with more active oxygen induced by Co doping. Strong interaction effects among Co-Mn-Ce-O were speculated as the main mechanisms underlying the high-efficiency catalytic capacity. The prepared Co-doped Mn-Ce mixed oxides catalyst may be a potential low-cost catalyst alternative to replace industrial noble metal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic deep combustion characteristics of benzene over cobalt doped Mn-Ce solid solution catalysts at lower temperatures
